38202737.review:
5年前通过看完ATE（听说当年动画至少回本了，但对于age来说算是扑街了，导致age本篇动画化继续流产......），第一次了解了这个游戏。后来在网上找了资源，也认真看了年表，还有各种设定。但由于安装苦手，没能玩上，今年终于得偿所愿。
很惭愧的是extra大部分都是跳着玩的，感觉有点无聊，unlimited基本上全程无快进，认认真真完成的，今天终于全成就了。同样看过知乎那篇帖子，屹立于人类历史约两万部galgame顶点的作品之一。alternative和无印一起入手的，接下来就准备开推了，说实话非常期待。
先简单说一下unlimited的感想吧。虽然unlimited还没有同BETA的直接接触，但是这是我见过对男主人公刻画的最好的一部GAL。
这一作心理描写简直太真实了，世界观宏大不说，气氛也烘托的恰到好处。或许比不上真正探究人性的文学作品，或者硬科幻小说，但是要知道它只是一个GAL啊。
白银武作为穿越者，没有任何外挂（除了战术机驾驶方面的特长），废柴到一无是处。BETA突破防线，即将上战场怕的要死甚至昏厥；从认为这个世界只是一场梦，到真正融入联合国横滨基地的207小队，与少女们同生共死，成为一个真正的卫士。
害怕是正常的啊，毕竟从73年BATA降落喀什建立HIVE1到现在，人类已经失去了六分之五的人口和大半领土。BETA跨过日本海登陆短短不到一周，日本就损失了3600万人，还有九州和四国两岛、本州岛沦陷大半。战场上，初次上阵的卫士的平均存活时间仅仅是八分钟。白银武所要面对的，就是这样残酷的世界啊……残酷到自我了断都是一种解脱的世界......
这才是最有代入感的主角，在战争面前，在星球和人类的存亡面前，我们渺小到连一丝波澜都无法掀起......但是即使是渺小到这样的自己，即使是连自己的命都不一定能保住，也会有坚持的东西，也会有想要守护的事物。
这就是MUV系列经久不衰的原因的冰山一角，不仅仅是宏大的世界观和叙事，单单就人类是命运共同体，将人类作为一个整体的概念这个立意就超过了绝大多数GAL……
可能会有人觉得unlimited不够精彩，说实话，我相信unlimited也只是一个铺垫罢了。三部曲环环相扣，从extra的纯日常，到unlimited的适应和转换，最后到alternative的爆发。这不仅仅是主人公白银武的成长，也是故事一步步走向高潮，走向巅峰的必不可少的过程。
说实话，现在这个时代，无论是我们，还是业界，都不比当年。当年对着秋之回忆能推上三天三夜，从来不回头看动画的自己，看了至少两三遍CL动画，花了两周时间推完游戏全线，还有强行啃圣诞之吻游戏的生肉。如今似乎找不到那种单纯而又耐心的感觉了，似乎也回不到那个为故事悲伤、欢笑的从前。还有逐渐套路化、模板化的业界，角色属性的堆砌和重复，商业化作品要多少有多少，一个人也没有那个经历去把所有GAL全部玩通。
所以说，变得无聊了，也不仅仅是因为我们不比从前了，也有业界逐渐药丸的缘故（误）
现在这个世界节奏太快了，大家都开始浮躁起来，对一部作品没有耐心，对自己的生活同样也没有耐心。不要思考三集定律，或者什么两小时，真正优秀的作品不是花片刻就能体会的到的，如果能静下心来认认真真体会MUV系列的故事的话，我相信你一定会被剧本的精彩所吸引。

(posting the same review for Muv Luv and Alternative)

If you're into the visual novel dating sim deal then you should probably play this. I'm told it's one of the best ones and it does a lot of... interesting stuff with that whole concept. If you're like me and indifferent to that but thinking about getting these two games for the mecha aspect, that's where it becomes really difficult to recommend. That part has a tendency to fall into the background for more than a few hours at a time once you finally get to it (takes about fifteen hours if i remember correctly), and if I'm being honest that's a good thing since it maybe wouldn't be able to carry your interest on it's own even if you're already a fan of the genre.

Not necessarily a knock on the game itself, I just came into it with the wrong expectations. This is very much an eroge visual novel about a ton of girls orbitting one oblivious dude's crotch, even if it does eventually involve giant robots and aliens and other sci-fi stuff. And if the former is your thing, again, this is almost certainly for you. But if you're just curious about the one super hyped up mecha visual novel you'll probably want to save yourself the time and money. While the mecha aspect definitely sees a huge jump in quality once you get to Alternative, you're talking about over 20 hours minimum to get there (I used a walkthrough), and even then it takes it's sweet time getting to (no spoilers) the parts you've actually wanted to see since halfway through the previous game, and would only stand up to average/slightly above average mecha anime or manga.

36516441.review:
Would not recommend to those who are not a fan of the genre. Muv-Luv is a romantic comedy. Don't start it just because you heard Unlimited and Alternative get more intense. The journey should be enjoyed in its entirety, including the tropey Japanese highschool romance parts, otherwise your enjoyment of the work as a whole will suffer.

That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed every minute of this light-hearted, but emotional journey. The art style was off-putting for me at first, but I grew to love it really quickly. This VN is solid all around. It has a good sense of humor and every character in the cast is well-developed and extremely lovable.

Pros:
+Catchy soundtrack
+Solid voice acting
+Great sense of humor
+Excellent light-hearted story that still has plenty of feels
+First half of story (Extra) has a lot of unique, well-developed branches
+Top-tier waifus
+Expressive ahoge

Cons:
-Art style takes some getting used to
-The genre isn't for everyone
-Second half (Unlimited) suffers from copy-paste story branches
-Second half arguably struggles to establish an appropriate tone

Overall, solid 9/10.
Strongly recommend to fans of the genre or anyone looking for a light-hearted story with just the right amount of feels to get you invested without leaving a hole in your soul when you finish.

マブラヴEXTRA編
          ↓
マブラヴUNLIMITED編
          ↓
マブラヴオルタネイティブ

と続きます。

批评空间和The Visual Novel Database网站都给了Muvluv比较一般的分数，我想这是个客观分数，都说欲扬先抑，Muvluv本篇两部应该就是这个“抑”。从Extra篇到Alternative篇，就是个“这是什么玩意儿”——"是个不错的故事"——“神作”的过程，所以我也希望因为Extra篇弃坑或者打算跳过本篇直接去Alternative篇的人都耐心推完三部。分开来说，Alternative篇的确是一大神作，本篇两部则比较普通，但是Alternative篇最终所表达的中心却是只有体会过本篇两部的人才能明白的，至于为什么，就留到Alternative那边的评测吧。

So I saw Muv Luv Alternative coming out and thought it looked interesting, as well as being drawn in by the claims it was the conclusion of one of the most acclaimed VNs of all time. So, wanting to see what the fuss was about, I got this one and started up.

I'm not too sure how I feel about Extra to be honest. It's a very well put together VN, don't get me wrong; decent writing, great characters (except for Takeru, the most insensitive protagonist I think I've ever played as) and well-drawn character and background art. But I felt as though I was still waiting for something significant to happen by the time it ended. However, that's probably a bit harsh on my part considering I haven't explored all Extra has to offer.

Unlimited, on the other hand, was definitely where I got heavily invested. Perhaps it's because I'm a sucker for giant robots, but that's not the only reason. The writing, art style and characters all kicked it up a notch. Even Takeru, insufferable he might've been, grew into someone who's somewhat admirable. While no tears were shed by the end of the game, the impact to my feels was definitely felt with the force of a TSF wielding a giant sledgehammer.

So yeah, I can now thoroughly accept this is one of the most acclaimed VNs ever, and going through all of this has me just itching to play Alternative to see how it ends. If you consider yourself a fan of visual novels, pick this up and enjoy the ride. Just make sure to grab a box of tissues just in case.

34537880.review:
[i]«The first 20+ hours of the game are spent in light hearted atmosphere where the player gets to interact with standard anime girls. Even the beginning of Muv-Luv: Alternative is a power trip where the supersoldier protagonist breezes through basic training and displays his superior piloting skills (mecha otakuness pays off in the end). AND THEN IT GRABS YOU BY THE HAIR, PULLS YOU UP AND STARTS F***ING YOU IN YOUR FACE.»[/i]
- Anonymous board user describing his experience with the Muv-Luv trilogy

[b]Muv-Luv[/b] is massive, by all means.

What on the first glance looks like a generic high-school-romance visual novel in fact turns into a dramatic SciFi / mecha / military-themed universe which took many influences from other franchises such as [i]Starship Troopers[/i], [i]Evangelion[/i] or [i]Gunbuster[/i]. The [b]Muv-Luv[/b] franchise was actually so successful that meanwhile it expanded into numerous sequels, spin-offs, light novels, anime series and much more.

To begin with, this particular release of [b]Muv-Luv[/b] consists of two separate games which you can select from in the main menu, [b]Extra[/b] and [b]Unlimited[/b]. [b]Extra[/b] can be considered as a lighthearted introduction to the main characters while [b]Unlimited[/b] finally introduces you to the serious SciFi world in which the franchise mainly takes place.

Personally I interpret both games as an overly long prologue to the amazing 50 hours long [b]Muv-Luv: Alternative[/b], the third game of the original trilogy which many players consider one of the best visual novels ever made ([i]not[/i] included in this particular release, sold separately). That being said you need to bring up the patience and effort to read through both [b]Extra[/b] and [b]Unlimited[/b], since in total it takes about 30 hours until you've seen all the endings. And to be honest, some routes and story branches in both games are not even that interesting. For instance I found [i]Ayamine's[/i] route in [b]Extra[/b] exhaustingly tedious.

BUT (and here it gets interesting) it still pays off if you read through everything and therefore immerse yourself into [b]Muv-Luv[/b]'s characters and world, since later in the third game a huge chunk of the story touches upon that. After sucking in all that what [b]Extra[/b] and [b]Unlimited[/b] offered, finishing the third game will be one of the most rewarding and complete visual novel experiences you might ever have.

Therefore especially [b]Extra[/b] may leave you rather unimpressed at first, but the experience definitely takes epic proportions by the time you finished both games and finally start [b]Alternative[/b].

In case you never played any visual novel before, here's the deal: You read yourself through textboxes and occassionally make decisions that to some extend change the outcome of the ending. Everything is accompanied by CGs, an appropiate soundtrack and sometimes even by voice actors. What may sound pretty boring to many is in fact pretty intense. Visual novels have the pace and format to tell such detailed and immersive stories that animes, movies or TV shows can't equally pull off due to their technical limitations. What a movie cramps down to 2 hours, a visual novel makes you experience in 40.

The story of [b]Muv-Luv[/b]  puts you in the shoes of Takeru, a regular, rather lazy Japanese high school student who's into mecha arcade games, good food and the comforts of life. He is best friends with Sumika, the girl next door who spent all her childhood with him. When he's not spending his spare time with her or his other buddy Mikoto in the local arcades, he's usually goofing around at school and interacting with his mostly female classmates. But everything changes as one day Takeru wakes up in his bed - next to a unknown, mysterious girl...

Telling anything more would already result in spoilers, but rest assured that you'll adore the [b]Muv-Luv[/b] trilogy if you like SciFi-themed anime with military / mecha / conspiracy / traumatizing vibes to it. The later parts specifically reminded me of Verhoeven's [b]Starship Troopers[/b], which I already mentioned before.

Now the [b]Muv-Luv[/b] games initially started as [i]Eroge[/i] visual novels with some kinky +18 scenes in it. This particular Steam release (also known as [i]All-Ages[/i] version) has all of the H-scenes removed due to Steam's content policies. The developers / publishers solved this problem by offering a separately available [b]Director's Cut patch[/b] that unlocks the +18 CGs in the game. While that's technically a good solution, the bad news is that you need to fork out another $10 for that patch, which is quite a rip-off in my opinion. In the end it doesn't even affect that many CG's and scenes, which are [i]pixelized[/i] anyway due to Japanese pornography law. Furthermore personally I didn't like the kinky scenes that much since they kinda feel out of place considering the intense story and all - but that's up to you.

So, should you get it?

If all that already sounds too long and tedious for you, then just leave it be. You'll most likely get bored after a few hours of listening to Sumika's annoying chatter.

But if you're ready to dive into this universe that later shines with excellent world-building and geekiness, then come on board and enjoy this rollercoaster full of excitement, emotions, blood and tears. Consider this release as an overly long prelude to [b]Muv-Luv: Alternative[/b], which will most likely blow you away completely.

6 out of 10 Yakisoba Pans, if you look at both first games from a individual perspective
8 out of 10 Henyus, if you put both first games it in context with the complete trilogy

Muv-Luv in all honesty is enthralling tale, about how vastly different one's perspective can shape the world, but most of all how the present is always changing and nothing is set in stone. Having taken approximately 42 hours to complete one ending for Extra and one for Unlimited, I feel I am now worthy to review this VN. Let's start from the beginning. Extra starts rather slow. It has solid amounts of comedy. Your typical slice-of-life setting. However, it really takes off in Unlimited. It is worth the wait, that is all I will say. Given the nature of Muv-Luv's narrative setup, the promotional videos and descriptions unfortunately kind of spoil the eventual flow of the plot, which makes Unlimited a tad less impactful, but by no means does it spoil the lot of it. 

It honestly reminds me of Steins;Gate, Sunrider, and eden*, all games which I have played/completed. Steins;Gate in the respect of it being slow to start, with a sudden significant realization that entirely shifts the narrative flow, and the pace gets exponentially faster. Sunrider with some of its sci-fi aspects. eden* with its narrative premise. Having solid knowledge on all four of the games, I have come to realize that they are related in more ways than one, and the satisfaction of that realization is/was amazing. Like an "Ah-hah" moment. In no way am I saying they were intentionally related, I am just mentioning what I realized and became so gitty about.

Furthermore, it stands the test of time. For being a VN from 2003, it's animations, character/background CGs, and audio are fairly impressive. And, for not being 4:3 aspect ratio, I salute this game. I'll admit that some of its soundtracks get kind of annoying and repetitive, but that was really no big downside. They were still enjoyable.

TL;DR: Can't wait for Alternative!

30022502.review:
Dieses Spiel ist ein Visual Novel (VN). Für alle, die neu in dem Genre sind: das heißt, es ist eine Geschichte, erzählt mit Untertiteln, mit bewegenden Bildern und leichten Animationen. Das Bild ist stetig im Wandel, somit kommt beim Lesen auch auf Dauer keine Langeweile auf. 
Die Sprache des Texts im Spiel ist Englisch, mit japanischer Synchronisation. Dies sollte man vorher beachten, um wirklich in den vollen Genuss des Spiels zu kommen. 
~
Muv-Luv erzählt eine lustige, herzerwärmende, traurige, spannende bis herzzerreißende Geschichte, die als Teeniekomödie/Romanze anfängt und in einem apokalyptischen Drama endet, in der aber einfach die ganze Chemie stimmt, was nicht zuletzt wegen des massiven Genre-Wechsels einen riesen Spaß macht. 
Es ist wirklich ein riesiges Paket. 
Dieser Teil ist der erste und dauert in einem Durchgang in etwa 12-15 Stunden. Und es gibt noch ein paar alternative Enden, die man erreichen kann. Nach 2 spezifischen Enden schaltet man dann 1.5 frei - Unlimited - welches ungefähr genau so lang und genau so viele verschiedene Enden bietet. 
Ich werde nicht mehr verraten, denn Spoiler sind doof. Es lohnt sich aber zuzuschlagen, denn für Langzeitmotivation gesorgt, ist allemal.

Es handelt sich hierbei um die PS3 Version des Visual Novels, welche stark geschnitten ist, sprich: keine Inhalte sind nicht jugendfrei. Allerdings ist ein gewisses Alter dennoch voraussetzbar, da das ganze nicht wie ein Märchen endet, recht komplexe Themen und Gefühle anspricht und daher doch eher an Erwachsene oder ältere Jugendliche gerichtet ist, um wirklich verstanden/genossen zu werden. Aber das ganze betrifft doch -eher- Alternative, den Nachfolger. Dieser Vorgänger ist dagegen ein Hauch im Wind, auch wenn ich schon hier die eine oder andere Träne vergießen musste - aus verschiedenen Gründen - ich bin wohl auch einfach zu nahe am Wasser gebaut. :)

Der Soundtrack (OST) stimmt immer passend mit dem Geschehen überein und geht auch von Anfang an recht gut ins Ohr. Wem dieser nicht zusagt, oder wem einzelne Sprecher nicht zusagen, so kann man diese auch muten. 
Die japanischen Stimmen sind allerdings alle gut vertont. Hier waren nur Profis am Werk.

Ich habe dieses Franchise erst nach Beendigung des kickstarters entdeckt, zuerst in der inoffiziellen Übersetzung, welche nun komplett überarbeitet wurde, und nun finde ich das Spiel unterhaltsamer als je zuvor. Wiederholungstäter können hier also guten Gewissens zugreifen. 

Fakten für Anime Fans:
*Hajime Isayama holte sich bei Muv-Luv Inspiration für Attack on Titan
*es gibt mehrere Manga, Light Novels (und mehr) und einige Anime, die im selben Universum spielen, letztere sind derzeit:
- Schwarzesmarken (Spin-off, welches zu DDR Zeiten in Deutschland spielt) - VN Übersetzung geplant
- Muv-Luv Alternative: Total Eclipse (Spin-off, spielt zur selben Zeit wie Muv-Luv Alternative) - VN Übersetzung geplant
- Kimi ga Nozomu Eien / Die Ewigkeit, die du dir wünschst (Pre-quel/spin-off; Drama/Romanze mit bekannten Gesichtern, wer Alternative schon kennt) - VN Übersetzung im Gange
- Akane Maniax (Sequel zu KimiNozo; Prequel zu Muv-Luv; allerdings reine Comedy)
- AyuMayu Gekijou (= Theater; Comedy, die man großteils erst versteht, wenn man das meiste, oder besser alle Einträge, dieser Liste abgearbeitet hat.)

Es sind noch mehr Übersetzungen von Spielen der Reihe geplant. Welche nun wirklich alle übersetzt werden und welche nicht, wird man dann erst sehen. Ich, für meinen Teil, kann von dieser Reihe nicht genug bekommen und jeder, der ihr eine Chance gibt, wird vermutlich bald genau so denken. 

Danke für's Lesen und diejenigen, welche ich mit meinem Review überzeugen konnte: 
Ich wünsche euch sehr viel Spaß!

29914908.review:
说来惭愧，作为一个穷逼，只能在游戏打折有一个比较合适的价格购买，以支持GAL游戏史上真正意义上的神作。
这是我之前玩过盗版之后写下的感想，终于能在今日为此游戏留下一点什么了。


花了5天时间，把MUV系列给推完了。这是我目前玩过战斗最具煽动性，同时剧情也是最绝望的GAL游戏。
虽然Extra和Unlimited部分着实无聊催眠，我也是花了两天不时按着快进才攻略女一女二的线路，对整部游戏有了大致的了解，甚至感觉浪费我的时间。但是到了Alternative部分，作品的散发气息完全变了，从揭开霞的真实身份开始，我再也没有快进过，生怕遗漏任何信息。剧情发展如潮水般停不下来，已经做不到多余的思考，只能接受被剧情的吸引，不断的看下去，完全找不到喘息的时间。随着逐渐了解真相，知道的越多，就越会对残酷的现实感到无能为力。

三场战争的描写尤其前两场能让我感受如此兴奋热血的ACG领域作品，要追溯到07年天元突破了。如果说天元突破是热血，MUV更多的是一种悲壮，更加残酷，更加现实。战争的冷血，面对强大未知的敌人的恐惧，军人的觉悟，描绘的实在是太有煽动性了。

男主角的成长历程也是众多GAL游戏难得的看点，中二男主角自以为有着超能力就可以拯救世界当救世主，却被残酷的现实打击的差点意识崩溃，将个人英雄主义轰的渣都不剩。所以看到男主角最后真正成长到一个“男人”的时候，我也变得无法讨厌这种男主角了，这是我在众多GAL游戏中少有的感受（虽然在最后一战的某段还是想抽他），不禁想到自己什么时候也能有这种翻天覆地的变化呢？

恋爱的主题，白色相簿2应该已是做到极致，无人能超越，但MUV男女主角跨越时空的爱恋也已足够煽情，让人叹惋不止。游戏有不少触到我泪点的桥段，还是非常感人的。

于是又回到开头，如果没有Extra和Unlimited的铺垫，Alternative真的还会这么成功吗，真的还会让玩家有这种痛不欲生的感受吗？Alternative的世界真的太残忍，之前开着后宫过着幸福和谐的校园生活，我真的好想回去，好好的珍惜，这应该是就是玩完整部作品，Extra和Unlimited所应该传递的吧。照这么想的话，它确实很好的完成了自身任务，但这并不能成为我可以给Extra和Unlimited高分的借口，缺点还是要承认的。如果当初AGE公司把校园生活写的更加有趣诙谐一些，悬念铺张更加吸引人一些，MUV系列必然会成为GAL领域的顶点，无人能及，当然这也是后话了。

因为MUV系列太出彩，对后世的作品也是存在潜移默化的影响。谏山创玩过这部作品后久久不能平静，立誓要创作出同样震撼人心的作品，于是就有了现在令人大呼过瘾的”进击的巨人”（目前最新一章也是看我的热血沸腾啊），魔法少女小圆前两集平淡无奇，但在第三集峰回路转，也是借鉴了MUV的一幕。像之后的命运石之门，罪恶王冠，都是有些MUV的影子。
目前steam上的MUV是Extra和Unlimited部分而且也无steam汉化版，所以我也不推荐购买，只适合打折用情怀去支持。如果哪天Alternative会登录steam，这个我肯定要百分百去支持的。

PS：女主角的声线真的好好听，很符合我的口味，而且演出卖力，充满变化，是所有女角色中最能直观感受性格的声音。但不知为什么好像不是很火，有点可惜。

给好评还是差评我真的很纠结，整体来看Extra和Unlimited是不可缺少的一部分，少了它们故事绝对不会达到顶峰；单拿出来质量却又太过一般，甚至无法让玩家产生兴趣玩下去。不过既然它出现在steam平台上，能让更多懂得它魅力的人来支持，给个好评吧！

29912662.review:
There are many reviews saying that this is one of the best visual novel in existence. They were not exaggerating. I have not read many visual novels but Muv Luv indeed feels like a one of a kind, unique in the way it approaches storytelling. 

Just having a good plot and cute girls will not automatically make the visual novel good. This visual novel uses large amounts of visual effects and sound effects (Despite being a visual novel) to bring life to the story. The viewer becomes immersed and engaged, as if you were inside the story feeling what the characters are feeling, seeing what the characters are seeing. 

The Muv Luv story is told in 2 parts, which are all carefully planned and executed. The difference in the mood between the 1st, 2nd part of this game is substantial, to the point where you can question if it was even the same game. Note, the story is not complete without Muv Luv Alternative, a sequel to this game which is not on steam. You have to play that after this to know the magnificence of the triology. This game, though not giving a satifying conclusion to ther story is still amazing on its own.

People going into this game expecting Mecha and a lot of action may be disappointed at the beginning with the seemingly ordinary high school setting in the beginning and even in the second part, but this may as well be treated as a prequel to Muv Luv Alternative where the Mecha action actually is. Those going into this expecting cute fluffy romance will find what they are looking for in the 1st part of Muv Luv, but the 2nd part will come as a shock. You will quickly realise that the 1st part is just there to make you lower your guard, to make you familiar with the main character’s feelings and then when plot advancement occurs you will be just as shocked as the main character.

If you play Muv Luv Alternative after this game, by the end the of that game you will be blown away by how flawless it was executed, showing us subtle hints and carefully placed foreshadowing’s in this game, which eventually lead to the build-up to the climax of the story and everything can be pieced together. 

Muv Luv can only be described as a piece of art. Not story is without flaws, this visual novel will leave many questions that require you to think deeply about it, but in the end you will be satisfied with the legendary ending of this story and look forward to playing the sequel which explains everything.

To end this review, don’t hesitate in buying this game. It is worth every penny and gives a solid 40+- hours of well executed story telling. You will marvel at its beauty in the end and have only one thought “Did I beat the game, or did the game beat me?”.

(P.S Make sure to play Muv Luv Alternative afterwards to truly know the marvel of this triology)

The first game, Muv-Luv Extra, is maybe 15 hours of bog-standard harem romcom. Y'know the type, dense protag, school setting, a half-dozen classmates of various waifu archetypes (Childhood friend and Ojou-sama being the main two). At the end you pick one and get a happy ending and it's all good, right? Well, now you're attached to the characters. All told, I found it enjoyable which is more than I can say for most haremshit.

Then you start Muv-Luv Unlimited. Aw yiss, my b-type otaku waifuge got a sequel, right?

You wake up in your bed. That's odd, usually one of the waifus wakes you up. Oh well, get dressed, grab your gameboy, go outside and there's the wreck of a giant robot lodged in your neighbor's house.

Childhood Friend's house is in ruins. So is the entire town. Dead trees, broken buildings, derelict mecha. So you walk up the hill to school, and your school is now a UN Military Base. The gate guards arrest you.

Turns out you're supposed to be one of the five billion or so casualties from the ongoing alien invasion that's turned most of Eurasia into a barren wasteland.

Muv-Luv Unlimited is about another 15-20 hours, and that sets the stage for Muv-Luv Alternative. Suffice to say that Extra gives you something to protect, and Unlimited gives you something to avoid. Alternative is where shit goes from 'pretty gud' to 'god-tier game'. The conclusion of the story isn't available on Steam (yet), but you can pick it up from the usual VN translation places.

Muv Luv (Steam) is the setup to one of the 'kamige', the best VNs of all time. I highly recommend it.

Muv-Luv is actually 3 main stories overall. This VN you are purchasing here however, is the first two stories, while Muv-Luv Alternative (the final story) is due sometime in the near future. What you get here is Muv-Luv Extra and Unlimited. One is a highschool harem romance as it is advertised to be and one is...well a military academy romance.

Let's start with Extra. It is cliche. It is a highschool romance by the book. The genre is generally very dull for me and while I enjoyed going through two routes, the other endings were a drag to go through. You have to start from the beginning for most of them. I skipped through most of the text I'd seen to speed this up because the writing isn't enjoyable to reread that many times. Basically, if you like highschool romance genre, shoot for it. You'll love it. I liked it, but I'm not over the moon for it.

Unlimited follows up on Extra. Unlimited is why I'm recommending this and why I am in love with it. The story is well written and works a lot more on world building, which makes it feel a lot more effort was put into it. Characters have modest development and the romance feels....less forced? I mean it is forced still, but you aren't being beaten over the head with it. It comes at an enjoyable pace for someone like me who cringes at that type of trope. It kept you wondering what was going to happen next unlike Extra which was pretty easy to guess because it was so tropey. The ending of the story is your choice, but [spoiler] it ends on a cliffhanger regardless [/spoiler]. Having seen the endings, I can say that I am genuinely excited for the conclusion for the trilogy when I came into this VN based on recommendation alone. 

Overall, buy it for Unlimited is just my personal recommendation. If you like sci-fi mechs, then do it. This story is really well done and sets you up for the finale.

28205475.review:
Alors Muv-Luv c'est quoi? 

- C'est un visual novel.

Un "roman visuel". Comprendre que vous allez voir défiler les images et les textes, sur fond musical, et tout ça va vous raconter une histoire, sur laquelle vous pouvez influer à des points clé avec des choix multiples, ces choix vous amenant à l'une des fins prévues par le script. Sur ce point Muv-Luv se caractérise par une liberté assez faible: peu de choix, et des scripts assez bateau. Il est facile de trouver son chemin et de tous les arpenter sans avoir un "walkthrough" à côté de soi. Rien avoir avec la douloureuse complexité d'un "Clannad" par exemple. Mais si l'histoire et le graphisme sont bon cette simplicité n'est pas un problème.

Alors parlons des graphismes. Ils sont bons... A part les personnages un peu caricaturaux et les coiffures extravagantes en mode XXL, mais on s'y fait assez vite. Le moteur est mis à contribution pour donner l'illusion d'action de manière souvent habile en agitant et déplaçant les images des personnages sur les fonds. On sent que d'épisode en épisode la maitrise de l'outil progresse. Et la transcription vers l'occident a été plus que soignée, l'ergonomie repensée et bien plus confortable. Techniquement du tout bon.
La musique? Excellente, particulièrement adaptée, jamais lassante.

L'histoire? Non, pas l'histoire: LES histoires.

Muv-Luv est en 3 parties: Muv-Luv Extra, Muv-Luv Unlimited, et Muv-Luv Alternative. Le produit qui est ici vendu rassemble les 2 premiers épisodes: Extra et Unlimited.

Muv-Luv Extra est un visual novel en milieu scolaire. Notre "héro" tout-ordinaire-et-facile-à-s'identifier se retrouve entouré d'une cour de jeunes filles avec chacune une histoire personnelle plus ou moins perturbée dans lequel il va falloir cheminer pour aller décrocher le cœur de ces belles. Mots-clés schonen, harem, school-life, du classique. Le scenario est pas trop mal ficelé, mais disons-le clairement, c'est niais. Non, ne partez pas. C'est la porte d'entrée de cet univers, avec des problèmes d'ados qui font des montagnes. Vous allez vous démener pour régler ces problèmes "immenses" et tout content passer à la suite, baigné de la fraicheur et de l'innocence qui transpirent de ce volume.

Muv-Luv Unlimited vous fait changer de dimension, dans tous les sens du terme. L'auteur vous pousse sans ménagement dans un univers si semblable, et en même temps si différent de celui de "Extra". Tout au long, vous vous débattez pour ne pas sombrer et à la fin, vous avez surnagé, plus ou moins... Plutôt moins... Plutôt pas... A la fin d'Unlimited vous avez tant bien que mal joué votre destinée et trouvé une issue la moins défavorable possible... Pour qui s'est laissé embarquer la meilleure fin reste douloureuse, insatisfaisante. 

Et c'est là que vous serez une fois ce jeu fini. Vous aurez vécu une aventure fraiche et naïve, suivi d'une aventure bien plus sombre. Les problèmes immenses du premier volume vous semblerons tellement relatifs à l'issue du second.

Et demain arrivera Muv-Luv Alternative.
Et là c'est la claque. Le voyage dans l'univers défini par "Unlimited" recommence, et le héro balloté par le torrent des évènements dans "Unlimited" tente de reprendre la main sur son destin dans "Alternative". Et lorsque l'on veut aller de l'avant, on s'expose. Ca sera dur, noir, violent... Il devra affronter une société organisée autour de la survie avec ses références culturelles d'une société paisible, naïve et replette. Il devra s'interroger sur le sens de son action, et si la fin justifie les moyens. Il ira au fond du désespoir, subira de plein fouet le décalage entre son vécu et les problèmes si importants dans le premier tome, si futiles dans ce dernier. C'est là que le visual novel deviens génial, capable de nous plonger dans la gêne, le désaroi, de celui qui reviens du front et trouve un monde futile au retour, de celui qui a de grandes aspirations mais doit faire du sale boulot pour atteindre des objectifs nobles. Mais nobles jusqu'ou? Sont ils vraiment nobles? Pas de bons, pas de méchants dans ce roman, juste des gens qui tentent de faire ce qu'ils croient le mieux. Alors oui des pointes de naïveté, des détours naratifs pas forcément utiles, des longueurs surgissent ici et là, mais ça reste du grandiose. Pas de quoi décrocher un prix Goncourt, mais bien, bien au delà de la plupart des visual novel.

Alors oui, "Extra" est moyen, "Unlimited" pas mal, "Alternative" colossal... Mais non, il ne faut pas faire l'impasse.

Commencer "Alternative" sans avoir lu "Extra" ni "Unlimited", c'est prétendre profiter d'un repas en ne mangeant que le dessert. Un bon déssert au bout d'un plantureux repas, c'est un met qu'on savoure. Si vous vous contentez du désert et sautez le repas ça aura la saveur du gateau du salon de thé: pas mauvais, mais sans perspective.

"Extra" et "Unlimited" plantent le décors, vous familiarisent avec les personnages, et avec le monde difficile qui attends Takeru. En arrivant dans "Alternative" après avoir lu les 2 autres vous saurez où vous êtes, qui vous entoure, et toute la profondeur du scénario se révèlera à vous. Le gouffre qui sépare Takeru de ses anciens amis vous montera toute son abîme. L'effet de la claque scénaristique sera décuplé, rien de moins.

Ce jeu comporte les 2 marches à monter pour atteindre le Nirvana qu'est "Alternative". Ne restez pas au pied de l'escalier. Montez, un grand voyage vous attends.

28035655.review:
Since a lot of reviews have already touched on most aspects of Muv-Luv, I'm going to list the things which stood out to me personally.

The Good:
- Outstanding production values. Sprites move, turn around and have a lot of variety. The camera also moves around quite and bit and isn't static like in most other VNs.
- No annoying moe characters who make stupid sounds and are generally annoying and useless. Even Tama can be quite savage when she wants to be. There is the maid trio but they get so little screen time that they can be easily ignored. Yes, I know Sumika can be pretty moe but she is straightforward and doesn't have an annoying squeky voice.
- The music generally fits whatever is going on, and some tracks are quite memorable.
- Has that old 90's anime feel to it.
- Good comedy and character development.
- Amazing attention to detail. Its the small things that make the world more realistic and believable.
- Improved translation which makes the whole thing flow better and easier to read.


The Bad:
- The art does hold up quite well when compared to other games released in the same timeframe, but it is still outdated by modern VN standards. Those giraffe necks are hard to unsee.
- Some parts can drag and some routes are just plain boring(most notably Tama's)
- The Lip-sync. This is an extra feature which they implemented only in the later all-ages version of the game and it shows. Its not very accurate and feels lazy compared to Alternative which had almost perfect lip-syncing. 
- The genre-shift of Unlimited is no secret at this point, but it feels like the store page gives away too much. I went into this knowing only that the story switches to sci-fi later on, and it was an amazing experience in itself just trying to figure out just when and how things were going to change.
- Too many things are left unexplained and you won't get the bigger picture until you play the sequel, Alternative.

Conclusion:

Extra: 7/10
Unlimited: 8/10
Overall: 7.5/10

Muv-Luv is a two part visual novel. First part is a standard rom-com and the second part is a sci-fi / adventure / action / mess. The Muv-Luv series has a large following and fanbase but a lot of it has to do with Alternative, the sequel to Extra and Unlimited.

The story, as already mentioned, is in two parts. Muv-Luv extra is a school rom-com. It is also exactly what you expect from a school rom-com, nothing special, nothing amazing. Just pull a few heartstrings, have a few laughs and there you have a successful rom-com. Nothing wrong with that mind, but some people might find it a bit dull. Unlimited, the second part, is a sci-fi / action / adventure / mess. The story itself is a bit cliché but again, and in my opinion, is not all that great. You spend most of the Unlimited story trying not to screw up your survival. The romantic routes barely differ from each other and it is very blunt about whose route you take.

The characters have very few unusual traits and are all terribly tropey. To drive a point home I will now state all of the main cast: the bland nice guy who all the ladies inexplicably fall for, the cute and dumb best friend, the bossy tsundere, the deredere, the one who doesn't speak much, the oblivious rich girl with no common sense, the mad scientist and the decent looking, kind teacher. It's like the guys who were looking for inspiriation played a game of darts with a trope stuck on both the triple score and single score areas, making it near impossible to make a non-tropey character and still win the darts match. I can't help but feel that despite the fact that they are likeable, they have very little depth.

The artwork, when looked at today, is ok. But you have to take into consideration that Muv-luv is over a decade old now, and when you notice that people still play it today without complaints about it, you realise that the artwork was pretty good. [i] Was [/i] good, but compared to some modern stuff, isn't actually that great but you can't expect it to be. So, fairly speaking, it has fared well. Another thing to state is that this is completely censored. I also couldn't care less about it and if you do, you can wait until later this month when the uncut patch is supposed to be released. The music, however, is nothing special. I could not pull any track out and call it great, but the soundtrack as a whole is not bad.

So in conclusion, the story of Extra is a standard school rom-com and you can expect exactly that out of it. You can expect it to pull a few heartstrings and to get a few laughs and all in all, have a good, dumb time. Unlimited, in my honest opinion was not great and while it too, does invoke some feels, it tends to drag on a bit. This is a critical part of the Muv-Luv series however and while it might not be everybody's cup of tea, if you intend to play Alternative you should play this. So if Alternative is what you are planning to play, you should start here. If you want to play a dumb rom-com VN then wait for it to go on to a good sale. If you want it uncensored, wait a few weeks (at time of edit, the patch has now been released). If you want to get into Muv-Luv I suggest you also wait for it to go on sale.

25401435.review:
This review is divided into three parts : 
What you will find in the game
Evaluation of each aspect of the game
Whether I recommend it or not.

Content

Muv Luv is what is called a visual novel. A visual novel is essentially a visual and audio interactive book. You read dialogues on static pictures while listening to the voices and music. From time to time you are offered with choices that could change the story. The gameplay is thus almost non-existent but that shouldn't stop from enjoying a visual novel if you can enjoy book.

Muv Luv contains actually two stories. The first one, Muv Luv Extra is about the daily life and romance of Shirogane Takeru, a Japanese high school student. The second, Muv Luv Unlimited, is about military training in an apocalyptic future. I can’t say anymore about that. Muv Luv Unlimited is closely linked with Muv Luv Extra so you absolutely have got to play Extra first.

To go into more details about Muv Luv Extra, there 6 girls you can date. Sumika, the childhood energetic girl, Meiya, the heir of one of the biggest company in the world, Tama, a friend that looks like a cat, Ayamine, the stoic girl and finally Sasaki, “iinchou”, the class president. All of them are very unique and enjoyable. Oh and yes, there is one more (or two) girls but...

The first story lasts about 20 hours. The second story also about 20 hours but then you can replay it by choosing another route (girl). Unfortunately the first half of the game will almost be the same. I only played Meiya and Sumika routes so I don’t know about the others.

Note that everyone is voiced in Japanese except Takeru, the main character. That is done deliberately to help you put you in the shoes of Takeru.  Feeling immersed in the Muv Luv is very important to enjoy it.

About the H content, there should be a free 18+ patch available later.

2. Evaluation

Graphics : Muv Luv was released in 2006, 10 years ago. Because the graphics are anime-styled, it doesn’t matter as much how old it is.The art style is different from most modern anime production ( less round, more straight) but I still think it is a plus. The interface looks and works very nicely. This is a huge improvement over the original game. They are a number of CGs but not that much compared to, say Fate Stay Night. Still, I think it is enough and moreover they are used effectively. Also because the sprites are well drawn, I would say the graphics are quite good for a visual novel. Rating : 4/5 . 

Musics : Like the graphics, I think they are very good and particularly fitting to each scene.  Nonetheless save for a few of them, they are not exceptionally good. Rating : ⅘

Gameplay : It’s a visual novel. Rating : ../5
Story : The story of Extra or Unlimited or even Alternative alone is not exceptional. However if you read Extra and Unlimited then it becomes great. If you add Alternative then it becomes exceptional. A masterpiece. That’s the reason it is seen as one of the very visual novel ever. Nonetheless, make no mistake, Extra alone is at least good and likely very good! It’s funny, light-hearted and touching. Rating of Extra and Unlimited: 4/5 if you don’t read Alternative. 7/5 if you read the trilogy.

Value for money : The price of Extra and Unlimited is about $28 and gives you more than 40 hours of content. A book costs about $6 and can be read in 5 hours if you’re very fast.So you have the same content as a book of the same price. Except you have pictures. And musics. And choices. It should be clear that Muv Luv is very good value for money. Rating : 5/5.

Final evaluation : 4.5 /5 a very good game

3. Recommendation

It should be clear that I strongly recommend it. However if you :
Don’t like reading
Don’t like comedy
Don’t like anime/manga (even so, maybe you could give it a try?)

Then you should not buy it. In the other cases, buy it and enjoy it at your leisure! You will have to wait for the climax, Alternative which should be released in December, anyways. I recommend you to at least clear Extra once first, preferably Sumika or Meiya and then play Unlimited.

[h1]Что из себя представляет Muv-Luv?[/h1]
В данной игре по сути сразу две новеллы: Muv-Luv Extra и Muv-Luv Unlimited. Вместе с третьей частью (Muv-Luv Alternative), которую обещают выпустить в Стиме в декабре 2016-го, они представляют единую трилогию. Перед началом прочтения я бы посоветовал сначала ознакомиться с Kimi ga Nozomu Eien и Akane Maniax.
Так как эти новеллы не были переведены на английский, можно посмотреть их аниме адаптации:

[url=http://anidb.net/a5470]Kimi ga Nozomu Eien: Next Season[/url]
[url=http://anidb.net/a2425]Akane Maniax[/url]

Дело в том, что в Muv-Luv упоминаются или даже напрямую участвуют некоторые персонажи из Kimi ga Nozomu Eien, а Akane Maniax является одновременно побочной историей Kimi ga Nozomu Eien и прямым приквелом к Muv-Luv: события Muv-Luv Extra начинаются на следующий день после концовки Akane Maniax.

В принципе, можно обойтись и без просмотра этих анимешек, но некоторые моменты (не самые важные) вам останутся непонятны.

[h1]Muv-Luv Extra[/h1]
На первый взгляд Extra представляет из себя типичную романтическую комедию про ОЯШа, на которого внезапно западают сразу несколько девушек. Но не дайте себя обмануть, если будете достаточно внимательны, то найдёте намёки на то что тишь и благодать Extra - это всего лишь затишье перед бурей.

Почти все концовки открываются довольно легко, в основном достаточно как обычно придерживаться вариантов с выбранной героиней и нужная концовка будет получена. Но с открытием концовки Common Ending 2 могут возникнуть проблемы. Если не можете её открыть, советую почитать прохождение.

[h1]Muv-Luv Unlimited[/h1]
В Unlimited на смену школьной комедии приходит научно-фантастическая драма с элементами меха-боевика. Но даже это всего лишь пролог к тому что ожидает нас в Alternative. После прохождения у вас останется довольно много вопросов, ответы на которые следует искать в третьей части.

[h1]После Unlimited[/h1]
После Unlimited, разумеется, нужно читать Alternative, которую многие считают лучшей новеллой за всю историю жанра. Её, как я уже писал выше, мы ждём в Стиме в декабре этого года.

Но и это ещё не всё, что есть в запасе у разработчиков. Серия Muv-Luv обросла многочисленными побочными играми, и для выхода в Стиме уже были анонсированы несколько из них:
[url=https://vndb.org/v15238]Muv-Luv Photonflowers*[/url]
[url=https://vndb.org/v15239]Muv-Luv Photonmelodies♮[/url]
[url=https://vndb.org/v14910]Schwarzesmarken[/url]

Кроме того на Anime Expo 2016 было объявлено о локализации Kimi Ga Nozomu Eien, так что она тоже наверняка заглянет в Стим.

[h1]Брать или нет?[/h1]
Если вы фанат жанра - брать однозначно. Это одна из тех новелл, которую обязательно нужно прочитать всем ценителям жанра. Если хотите прочесть все три части залпом, то, возможно, вам стоит подождать выхода Alternative в декабре. Там как раз зимняя распродажа будет, так что сможете взять первые две части со скидкой.

Full Disclosure: I backed the Kickstarter for Muv-Luv to the tune of $300, thus I do hold a bit of bias if only for the sake of justifying my puchase

Muv-Luv is an interesting visual novel conceptually, a Sci-Fi trilogy that at the time of its original release was sold simply as a romantic comedy. This is a remake of sorts, it runs on a new engine, some voice work was redone, there's support for widescreen and the biggest change of all is the fact that the plot twist is now shown upfront most likely due to it being a fairly old title that has had plenty of time for said twist to be considered less integral.
This particular iteration consists of Extra and Unlimited, with the third part Alternatvie being a more linear experience but just as long if not longer than both previous parts combined. Extra is the first part, taking place in a traditional school setting. It's a romantic comedy wherein the protagonist, Shirogane Takeru must choose between five different girls, the main two love interests being Mitsurugi Meiya, the mysterious heir to a large financial conglomorate whom Takeru finds in his bed one fateful morning and Kagami Sumika, Takeru's long-time childhood friend who's beginning to desire their relationship to be something more. Your route in Extra is determined by various choices you make over the course of the game, one of the typical choices involving which girl's lunch you choose to eat. It's recommended that you go through the routes of both main heroines before entering Unlimited. 
Unlimited shifts both in tone and setting, while still retaining the root of Extra, it's much more serious in comparison taking place in an alternate world where Kagami Sumika doesn't exist and an alien threat referred to as the BETA have ravaged the world, leaving only one billion humans left on Earth. This part acts mainly as a setup to the world of Unlimited, Takeru's growth as a person and to show the differences between the worlds besides the painfully obvious. The routes in this part are much easier to get, as it's left down to about three divisive choices around the end, and five of the six possible character endings have both a Normal and Good variant. Unlimited primarily acts as build up to the finale, Alternative however it still acts self-contained as does Extra so you don't have to progress down the line if you don't want to. 
All in all I'd recommend picking this up if you're a fan of VNs and mecha, it's not everyone's thing but is fairly unique in its concept and execution and I certainly enjoyed it more than I expected to.

In the interest of full disclosure, I’d like to begin by saying that I backed [i]Muv-Luv[/i] during its Kickstarter campaign. I’ve also read [i]Muv-Luv[/i] and its sequel, [i]Muv-Luv Alternative[/i] prior to reading the official Steam release, so my hours played (51 hours as of this writing) don’t accurately reflect the amount of time I’ve actually spent reading this series. Regardless of my status as a Kickstarter backer, however, I don’t intend to pull any punches in my review.

For those who are unfamiliar with this title, Muv-Luv is actually comprised of two visual novels: [i]Muv-Luv Extra[/i] and its sequel [i]Muv-Luv Unlimited[/i]. Together, they comprise part one and two of a trilogy, concluded in their sequel, [i]Muv-Luv Alternative[/i]. 

Taken on its own, [i]Muv-Luv Extra[/i]—the first installment in the trilogy—is an unremarkable school life comedy mired in well-worn harem anime/manga tropes and stock character types (the childhood friend and the mysterious transfer student, to name two). True to the conventions of the harem genre, a clueless and insensitive male protagonist finds himself surrounded by five young women who pine over him in spite of his complete obliviousness to their thinly veiled romantic advances. Aside from a few amusing moments that arise from the absurdity of the situations therein, the most polite way to describe [i]Extra[/i] would be that it is forgettable. One of its most egregious issues lies in the overlong, circuitous writing style on display in particular sections, where the story grinds to a halt in service of back and forth exchanges that have no significant impact on the narrative. This could have been greatly improved by simply removing “problem” scenes or dialogue sections wholesale. All that being said, you’d be doing yourself a huge disservice by skipping directly to [i]Muv-Luv Unlimited[/i] without at least playing through Sumika and Meiya’s routes (more on this in a moment).

In spite of [i]Muv-Luv Extra[/i]’s failings, however, [i]Muv-Luv[/i] it more than makes up for most of them in its direct sequel, [i]Muv-Luv Unlimited[/i]. Without giving too much away, [i]Muv-Luv Unlimited[/i]—and its sequel, [i]Muv-Luv Alternative[/i] (not yet released as of this writing)—are extremely different in genre, tone, and overall themes to their predecessor, [i]Muv-Luv Extra[/i].* This shift is crucial to understanding how [i]Unlimited[/i] succeeds in many areas where [i]Extra[/i] fell short. Its greatest triumph arguably lies in the way it recontextualizes everything the reader knows about [i]Extra[/i]’s world, while anchoring it to the characterization of its female leads in ways that are by turns expected and surprising. Now, you may be wondering: if [i]Unlimited[/i] is so much better than its predecessor, why bother with [i]Extra[/i] at all? The answer is simple: you'll miss out on valuable plot and character information if you decide to skip it; I strongly recommend reading through at least Sumika and Meiya’s routes in [i]Extra[/i] before diving into [i]Unlimited[/i].

Unfortunately, however, some serious issues from [i]Extra[/i] persist, including its heavy-handed harem antics and thoroughly unlikable protagonist. While not quite as pronounced as they were in [i]Extra[/i], they nonetheless detract from [i]Unlimited[/i]'s much more interesting story (the same holds true for its sequel, [i]Alternative[/i]).

If you have the patience for a slow-burn story with a great payoff and are willing to forgive [i]Muv-Luv's[/i] overbearing genre idiosyncrasies, I would strongly recommend [i]Muv-Luv[/i]. Don’t make the mistake of skipping [i]Extra[/i], though; it will pay dividends if you stick with it, greatly enriching your understanding of [i]Unlimited[/i]’s characters.

*MAJOR SPOILER: 

[spoiler]Transitioning from an insipid slice of life drama to a military sci-fi epic--albeit one that can't quite shake its irritating harem genre trappings (more on this later in the review).[/spoiler]

24586744.review:
Muv-luv is a collection of visual novels, with the series overall regarded as a top-tier entry in the genre. The two games out right now are Extra and Unlimited. The order of the series is Extra -> Unlimited -> Alternative, and it is highly recommended you play them in order. I jumped into these games without knowing much of anything about then because I heard a lot critical acclaim for the series, and I don't regret my decision.

Extra is considered the least intriguing of the group, and I would have to agree. It’s a fairly time SOL game. The kind where the extremely average, nearly faceless lead character somehow amasses a handful of girls who are eager to aim right for his groin with the precious of a heat-seeking missiles. It features a lot of slapstick comedy (most of it based on tried-and-true genre clichés, some of it actually funny). It took me a while to warm up since it wasn’t all that interesting (no overarching plot), but in the end I enjoyed the characters and the various scenarios their personalities brought about.
Unlimited is where the series starts to reveal its true colors. Starting a short while before the conclusion of Extra, Takeru awakes in his bed one morning to find the world outside a devastated wreck. Although he initially believes it to be a dream, he is soon confronted with the fact that he has somehow ended up in a parallel world where humanity has been at war with aliens since the 60s. Seeing the ways in which the world and the characters that had become so familiar during Extra have diverged due to this new history is one of my favorite things about Unlimited. 

The game comes with the option to play either entry whenever, although again if you're a newcomer you'll want to go in order. There are a ton of save spots, always nice when a game features a lot of choices, and I like that the game instantly resumes from where ever I felt off when I reopen it. That a pretty neat feature I've never come across before.

The spritework is interesting as well. Characters move into the foreground and background accordingly, providing some depth and additional animation to scenes. There aren’t a ton of CGs, and some see a fair amount of re-use. Some silly scenes see the inclusion of chibi drawings that look like they’re drawn with crayon. I have noticed sometimes the characters seem to lag or freeze when they’re in the middle of changing poses or facial expressions, and while it doesn’t happen often it is noticeable.  

The music is alright. To be honest, while I realize music can add a lot of emotional impact I generally don’t ding games much on that area unless a significant portion of the soundtrack is actually bad. For the most part the music is certainly… there, some of it is even a little catchy, and the tracks chosen match up with the flavor of the scenes they play in, but at this point I haven’t heard anything that blew my socks off. 

The series does have a large amount of time investment, and while I wasn’t entirely sold during the first few hours with Extra I can now see places where the hinted at the series’ true nature. I grew to really enjoy the characters, and so far Unlimited has me enthralled. 
I'll update this review with more thoughts as I finish the games. Maybe.

24584515.review:
(This review contains minor spoilers for Muv-Luv Extra/Muv-Luv Unlimited/Muv-Luv Alternative; however, it shouldn’t detract from the overall enjoyment of reading the Muv-Luv franchise) 
This review covers Muv-Luv Extra/Muv-Luv Unlimited and Muv-Luv Alternative. 

What is Muv-Luv Extra/Unlimited/Alternative? 
__________
Muv-Luv is a Visual Novel franchise that is divided into 3 parts, namely (Part 1) Extra, (Part 2) Unlimited, and (Part 3) Alternative with each subsequent part following on the previous one. 

Extra starts off as a generic romcom story without much depth. The main character Shirogane Takeru tries to gain affection from a variety heroines to unlock each heroine’s respective ending while comedy ensues. However, events take a much darker turn during Unlimited and Alternative where the peaceful lives of everyone turns into a bloodbath and fight for survival. 

The Muv-Luv franchise gets the majority of its praise from Alternative which is considered a masterpiece from several people among the anime community (myself included). The unfortunate part is that, except for being a slightly above average romcom Extra doesn't have much depth and just can't compare to its sequel (Alternative); however, it still plays a vital part in building the foundation of the Muv-Luv franchise and thus shouldn’t be skipped.
 I do however recommend to rather wait for Muv-Luv Alternative to release before playing Muv-Luv Extra and Unlimited.
 

Story: 
__________
If I were asked to describe the story of the Muv-Luv franchise in one sentence, it would be the following: 
“The Muv-Luv franchise tells the story of Shirogane Takeru and his quest to find meaning to his existence and the role he can play in shaping everyone's lives around him.” This holds true to all 3 parts in the Muv-Luv franchise, albeit in vastly different ways. 
During the first part Muv-Luv is a casual romcom and Takeru has to solve the problems from each heroine in Muv-Luv while also romancing them to unlock each heroine’s ending. 
During Unlimited and Alternative Takeru finds himself in an alternative timeline from his own. Instead of facing trivial problems like training for a lacrosse match from his initial timeline he is caught up in a war with aliens called BETA to determine the fate of humanity. It tells the epic story of how Takeru faces hardships and how he tries to overcome each obstacle that is thrown his way, while still maintaining his sanity. 

Characters: 
__________ 
Q: What defines a perfect character? 
A: An imperfect character. 
Muv-Luv contains a large cast of characters who all get a fair amount of screen time, however the one similarity all of them share is the fact that none of them are perfect. 
During Muv-Luv Extra the opinion you will initially have regarding the characters will be that most of them are without any glaringly obvious flaws and that they are perfect. As you continue with Unlimited and Alternative these specific characters that you might have idolized will crush your expectations of them when you realize that they are also merely “human” and that they can also only deal with so much before finally breaking. 
The whole cast of Muv-Luv remind me of a form of art called Kintsugi. Kintsugi (金継ぎ) means “to repair with gold”. It is the process in which a broken pot or bowl would be pieced together with gold or silver to form something stronger and more beautiful than before it was broken. Each character in Muv-Luv has flaws, but it’s these flaws along with their progression and growth that make them unique and makes you feel attachment towards them. 

Gameplay:
__________
Muv-Luv is a Visual Novel and as the word suggests it is a novel with visuals and sounds. It doesn’t contain any gameplay elements and the only real interaction between the reader and the game is making choices during dialogue and seeing the outcome of said choices. 
If you are looking for a game with gameplay, then skip this it’s probably not for you. However, if you don’t mind treating it as a book with sound and visuals then you might find yourself pleasantly surprised. 


Sound & Art:
 __________
Seeing as Muv-Luv is a Visual Novel the sound and art play a great role in influencing how the reader perceives the characters as well as the world itself. 
Muv-Luv’s graphics, sprites and CG no longer hold up to more modern Visual Novels; however, they fulfill the task that they set out to do which is delivering an immersive experience. 
Muv-Luv has excellent music, sound and voice acting and despite it being almost 3 years since I originally read Muv-Luv (Fan translation) I still remember what each character sounds like as well as most songs from the soundtrack.

Overall thoughts:
 ___________ 
Muv-Luv is a visual novel and should be treated as such. It contains virtually no gameplay elements. The story of Muv-Luv Extra starts slow and quite generic; however, after you reach Unlimited it becomes a lot more interesting and the overall pace of the Visual Novel picks up and continues to do so until it finally reaches its climax delivering a truly epic experience. 

Who is it for? 
__________
Patient people who want to read an exceptional story, and are willing to sit through a few hours of mediocrity to achieve it.

24514872.review:
It is incredibly difficult to explain what makes Muv-Luv as good as it is without at least partially ruining one of the major events within this game. So difficult, in fact, that the marketing blurb on this very steam page 13 years after the Japanese release (yes, this game is 13 years old) does just that. I will try to give my thoughts without revealing anything the store page has not already, but with that said *POTENTIAL SPOILERS AHEAD*


[u] 1. Thoughts on the game as a whole:	[/u]


At first, you may think this game another typical dating sim-esque visual novel, in the vein of games such as NEKOPARA which have appeared on Steam in the last couple of years. You could be forgiven, as you wouldn't be [i] entirely [/i]wrong. This title is split into 2 parts; a light-hearted and cliche slice of life comedy (Dubbed 'EXTRA'), and a significantly more serious, alternate universe affair that parallels the first half of the title (Unlimited). Curiously enough, the developers of this localisation have decided to allow both routes to be immediately playable upon launching the game, though I cannot stress enough the importance to play this game in the correct order. The contrast, foreshadowing and tonal shift are all essential elements which elevate this game, particularly the first section, to something greater than the sum of its parts.

The general consensus among fans of the franchise is that the first portion of this game, EXTRA, is something worth slogging through in order to reach Unlimited and the (as of yet unreleased on steam) sequel, Alternative. While I cannot deny that the latter 2 games are definitely the meat and potato of the series, with Alternative in particular considered by many to be the greatest visual novel of all time, I have to confess that personally I find EXTRA to be legitimately enjoyable. While it is nothing special on its own by any standards, it is a genuinely funny, short and sweet experience with very likable characters that manages to never take itself too seriously. I would happily give it an 8/10 on its own merits.

Unlimited, on the other hand, is undoubtedly the highlight of this game. Introducing the world and story that will carry over into the sequel, Alternative, the game begins to show its true colours, and is a tense, sobering sucker punch of a follow-up act to EXTRA. At this point, the series really does become one of the all-time greats of the mecha genre.This chapter of the game, paired with Alternative, is what I consider to be quite honestly one of the best works of science fiction ever made. If EXTRA is an 8/10, then Unlimited is quite easily a 9/10.


[u] 2. Thoughs on the localisation: [/u]

As a reader of the original release and a backer of the Kickstarter that accompanied this steam version, I can say that Degica have mostly done a fantastic job and porting this game on to Steam. They listened to the fans when it came to features we wanted to see implemented, and the game has released in a very polished state. Particularly, the ability to switch between English and Japanese text on the fly is a fantastic feature. The official translation reads very smoothly, and is less overly literal than the fan translation sometimes had a habit of being. The dialogue does at times feel almost [i] too [/i] colloquial however, with mannerisms feeling a little too '2016 America' for their own good. This is clearly an intentional decision by the translation team, however, and is really just a matter of personal taste.

Some people also seem to be unhappy with the presence of censoring in this title when compared to the original release, particularly with regards to the 'adult content'. These scenes were few and far between in the original release anyway, and in my opinion took more away from the game than it added. There is supposed to be a patch eventually from the developer's website to rectify this regardless, if that's your cup of tea.

            --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
           

Overall, if you have an even a fleeting interest in the concept of this visual novel, I cannot recommend it enough, and the sequel alone makes this game an absolute must-buy.

Premise: it's my second time reading Muv-Luv, which means that I'm familiar with both the fan-translated version and the Steam one.

Muv-Luv contains the first (Extra) and the second (Unlimited) part of the trilogy. The conclusion will come out later this year (Alternative). Let's start by introducing the story.

EXTRA

This is the part that you'll want to play first (this version allows you to go straight for Unlimited, which you should NOT do). It's a generic slice-of-life rom-com in a highschool setting, and it features Takeru, your run-of-the-mill carefree protagonist who's surrounded by cute girls but is totally unaware of their feelings for him. Takeru wakes up one day to find a mysterious girl sleeping in his bed. His childhood friend, Sumika, who comes wake him up every morning and has a crush on him, is not very happy about that. Shenanigans ensue. In order to ensure the best possible experience, you should at least read Sumika's and Meiya's routes, but I'd still recommend going for all of them.

UNLIMITED

PLOT TWIST! Takeru wakes up one day and finds out that the whole city around him is in ruins. Not only that, it seems that a huge mecha has crashed into Sumika's house! Understandably confused, he starts walking around town towards his highschool, which is now... a military base, for some reason. It soon becomes clear that our hero has stepped into an alternate dimension where humanity is on the brink of extinction after decades of war against a seemingly undefeatable race of aliens, the BETA. How did he end up there? Will he ever be able to go back to his own world? Or will he stay and help humanity's struggle for survival?

I really need to make this clear: Muv-Luv is nothing special by itself. It's not supposed to be played by itself. It's not self-sufficient at all. If you buy this, then you'd better be ready to buy Alternative in a few months, otherwise don't even bother. I promise it will be worth it. This trilogy has a pretty high barrier of entry, you'll need to invest at least 50-60 hours in it before it really gets good (most likely more than that), but the payoff will be immense. MLA will take you on one of the wildest rides you've ever experienced, but it wouldn't be even half as good without Extra/Unlimited. So yeah, don't expect this game to be good on its own, it's not, it was never meant to.

Now, to be fair there are some differences from the original version that I feel I have to point out. First of all, the default resolution is 1024x600 instead of 800x600, which means that most CGs had to be cropped. I wasn't particularly bothered by this, but others might be. Secondly, a couple tracks from the soundtrack had to be replaced because of licensing problems. I don't particularly mind about the one in Unlimited (I don't even know what it's called), but I really miss the other one (Warudakumi, a.k.a. the "Livin la Vida Loca ripoff"). That was one of the best things in this game, and I'm completely serious here. The new translation is pretty good, some might dislike it for not being 100% faithful but I don't really care, I personally think that a good translation should read well in the target language, and this one certainly does. I would have done without the Linkin Park reference though.

So, to sum things up: this VN is not for everyone. If you don't intend to read this trilogy "seriously" (if that makes sense), don't bother, you'll just waste time and energy. If, however, you have the dedication to go from start to finish, you won't regret it.

Une sorte de parodie dopée aux hormones qui ne recule devant rien pour s'assurer de divertir et faire rire mais qui au final ne semble que grotesque et forcée. Pas qu'Extra soit complètement raté, il en a même de très bons qui sonnent justes et certains lecteurs l'apprécieront même pour ce qu'il est, mais difficile de s'en satisfaire tant son histoire semble partir constamment dans tous les sens. Son vrai mérite est d'introduire les personnages dans un contexte "normal" (aussi normal que puisse être le monde de Muv-Luv Extra).

Avec Unlimited l'histoire subit un changement dramatique de ton et de contexte. Le récit devient plus sérieux, malgré des passages comiques bien plus maitrisés ici et là, et des enjeux concrets apparaissent. Pourtant même si sa lecture est plus agréable Unlimited n'est pas sans défauts non plus, arrivé à la fin on peut légitimement se demander ce qu'il raconte tant rien n'a été réglé. Son rôle au sein de la trilogie est de d'introduire et développer le monde dans lequel Alternative prendra place.

Au final on fini ce VN en ayant l'impression de n'avoir lu que deux longues introduction au véritable récit promis. Et c'est exactement le cas.

Alors ce Muv-Luv vaut-il la lecture ? La réponse est sans l'ombre d'un doute OUI.

Ça sera probablement un peu chiant et long par moments, mais courage, le Shangri-La méchaphile vous tends les bras dans la suite et votre persistance sera alors amplement récompensée.

Summary: Muv-Luv (Extra and Unlimited) starts off as Slife-Of-Life and Romance Comedy but establishes a great build-up for an emotional coming-to-age story with Muv-Luv Alternative (releasing in near future). 

My Rating for [b]Muv-Luv by itself: 7.5/10[/b]
Rating for [b]Muv-Luv as part of Triology : 9/10[/b]

*note, this rating is given with consideration that one is not particularly discouraged by Japanese ACG tropes. Individuals who aren't into enjoyment or appreciation of such culture may choose ignore this*
===============================================
First, a few FAQs before actual review.

-This is a Visual Novel, where the main entertainment is the storytelling with choice-consequence effect throughout the VN. Thus, there isn't much of a gameplay apart from texts, dialogues and choice selections so please kindly not compare these with mainstream games. 

-Muv-Luv was first released back in 2003 for PC with heavy influences of Galge genre of VNs. At such, it might seem generic with fanservice similar to a lot of animes at first. However, there are more to it for the Muv-Luv triology which I'll explain in my review later.

Muv-Luv is considered a triology consisting of 3 parts, aka [b]Extra, Unlimited and Alternative[/b], with the first 2 part released together in this VN and the last part available in the upcoming release of Muv-Luv Alternative. These parts can be played as standalone without the need of the following story arc. Each playthrough across different story arcs delivers a new twist/taste that builds upon the setup on previous parts of the triology. The VNs are [b]highly rated in VNDB[/b], a visual novel database for western fanbase. Muv-Luv Alternative is being rated as first place, though many fans agree that this score is given based on the overall enjoyment of the triology.

To avoid plot spoilers, I can only give a general overview. [b]Extra[/b] offers the experience one can expect from [b]slice-of-life or romance stories[/b] and acts as a parody for the related tropes in these genres. However, this is specifically written in such a manner to enable readers to get acquainted to the characters' personality to setup for further development. Unlimited then builds upon these bonds to setup a new premise for story progression. While retaining it's slice-of-life moments, Unlimited [b]delivers a more serious background[/b] revolving around familiar characters. Again, the ending for Unlimited can serve as a standalone story without Alternative despite mixed opinion, but it definitely offers a greater story when read together with Alternative.

With the origin of Muv-Luv in mind, there are considerable amount of [b]fanservice elements[/b] in the VNs, especially in Extra and Unlimited. This often leads to a misperception of what Muv-Luv offers as general community are more familiar to anime or fanservice aspects of similar VN/game. However, Muv-Luv is meant to [b]relay a deeper and grander emotional experience[/b] when readers progress through the triology, even if Extra starts of as cliche and fanservice-y. Thus, I highly recommend going through the trilogy by Extra>Unlimited>Alternative despite the ability to skip directly into Unlimited in the current release. Apologies if you do find my review vague in regards to the plot but this is something best experience by accompanying the characters through [b]a coming-to-age story[/b]. You'll find a more detailed review by the time Alternative comes out.

Also, do note again that this VN was first released back in 2003. Some have nitpicked that the story is not as revolutionary as acclaimed but I do want to point out that the details in writing and tie-in across the triology was unique at the time of release. And it still remains impressive with few fictional works able to match similar experience. The current translation was greatly improved in comparison to the old fan translation so even returning readers can experience a fresh playthrough.

Need something else to convince you? Cool.
The KickStarter for English Localization got funded USD$1,255,444 by 7,890 backers, with initial goal of $250,000 reached in nearly 6 hours after launch.
Now, ask yourself: Why such a big success if it's just visual novel which hasn't entered the mainstream entertainment in the West? *wink*

As a campaign backer and longtime fan, I’m pleased to see this awesome VN finally on Steam. When I first laid hands on the Muv-Luv series a few years ago, two thoughts instantly crossed to my mind: 

1. This looks like a fun trip. 
2. Best Girl’s easy to spot by her purple hair and elegant demeanor. 

There was never any doubt about the second point. But boy, was I wrong about the first one. So yeah: you're in for one hell of a ride. Though there’s a bunch of words to describe the journey, you’ll need to look closely at the end of the line, to finally find “fun”. But we’re still talking about Extra and Unlimited here (and not Alternative, which will hit Steam on a later date) so let’s stick with “fun” for now. 

All starts as a whacky and lighthearted romantic comedy, with your typical dense protagonist Takeru and his gang of potential love interests. It’s all nice and cute, but there’s nothing outstanding there, so a lot people ask, if there's any loss in skipping or rushing through Extra. - Well, there is. Because at some point into the series, you’ll notice, that it’s all part of the greater picture and every part’s crucial to grasp the saga and its impact as a whole. In fact, it’s pretty reasonable to see Extra as one long prolog to the core story, which starts with Unlimited and also a drastic change in tone and setting. 

Through mysterious circumstances, Takeru awakes in an alternative timeline, where mankind is stuck in a desperate fight for survival against an alien race known as BETA. Gone are the dull days of Extra and you’re thrown right into a far more serious and darker universe, with very strong SciFi/Mecha themes. Saying much more about the story would be high treason, but let me assure you: it was worth every single one of the many hours, I spend in front of the screen. The story sometimes drags itself through extensive explanations, yes. But overall, it’s woven nice and tightly (there’s no perfection when it comes to time travel/alternate timelines) and plays with some interesting concepts. 

In short: this is a definitive worth-your-money recommendation. And if you perchance still think of “fun” when the credits roll, keep in mind: by the time Alternative arrives, you’ll have to learn the hard way, how utterly and dreadfully wrong you were. 

Pros:

- Intriguing Story, which –with Extra- lulls you into a false sense of mildly amusing harmlessness and sets the stage for the magnificent main event, known as Alternative.
- Still nice production values for a VN originally released in 2003.
- Length. You may want to reschedule your golf lessons, meetings and dinner with your waifu  to dig through this. You’ll be busy for a while. Roughly around 50 hours (and more), I’d say. 
- Reasonable price 
- Meiya 
- Kasumi 
In that order. 

Cons:

- Extra alone is barely nice, tumbling on the brink of boredom here and there. Nonetheless a day will come, where you’ll yearn for this innocent times gone by
- Story drags here and there with its excessive explanations. Not as extreme as in Alternative, but still more than enough.
