24326171.review:
This isn't so much a review as a recommendation. TL;DR: this is mandatory reading for visual novel fans even though, by itself, it isn't all too great (yet). Also, FOR THE LOVE OF GOD DO NOT SKIP EXTRA. Also, FUCK LACROSSE.

===Why does this game matter?===

If you like visual novels, you pretty much need to play all of MuvLuv. It's one of the most well-respected visual novel franchises ever and is a staple of the medium. It's also the highest-rated VN on VNDB by a commanding margin.

The problem is that the REASON it's so well-received isn't really present in this chapter of the story. This entire product is pretty much entirely buildup for one of the greatest stories to come out of Japanese anime culture, MuvLuv Alternative. 

To make things clear, there are three main chapters of MuvLuv: Extra, Unlimited, and Alternative. The first two are included in this Steam product and the third, Alternative, is on its way. 

This Steam product is still better than the majority of visual novels on Steam at the moment (though that's more a testament to the shitty state of VNs in the West at the moment) but if you are expecting something as story-rich as Steins;Gate, Umineko, or CLANNAD, you will be disappointed. 

Until Alternative comes out. 

===Is it worth it to put in 20 hours into a game just so I can read the sequel?===
Yes. Absolutely yes. There is no doubt in my mind that anybody who is willing to put in the investment will be blown away by Alternative. I mean it. I have never met anybody who finished Alternative who didn't value that experience or ended up regretting sticking with it 'til the end.

It's fucking amazing, that's why. There is so much I can say WORKS about Alternative, but I don't want to lose focus here. I feel it's worth saying that this is a sci-fi / mech story, but that's not really the focus of the series --- most of the thematic content deals with the human element of warfare, which doesn't sound like a unique concept, but Alternative's spin on things is groundbreaking (at least for the medium and for anime as a whole).

===How is the localization?===
Altogether it's pretty great, even though there are some changes I found strange or didn't like. The translation is still spot-on, the game is stable, and there are new BGMs which are alright. I wasn't a fan of how they replaced the Unlimited OP, but YMMV. Seeing this game in Alternative's aspect ratio was a little jarring at first and might reduce some of the anticipation for Alternative (since, for me, a huge part of the HYPE was seeing the massive increase in production quality between MuvLuv and Alternative, an effect which will probably be dampened here) but I understand why they did it. 

Something I'm really not a big fan of is how they allow the player to bypass Extra and jump right into Unlimited. For those about to read the VN, you absolutely MUST NOT skip Extra. Play at least one route. Trust me. The entirety of Unlimited is predicated on the fact that you read routes from Extra. I can't imagine it working as well otherwise.

However, I can't be too salty, since it's really amazing that this game in particular was able to be localized at all. I'm altogether thankful for Degica for bringing this to the West so I can rekindle my luv for MuvLuv.

===In conclusion===
Play this game. You'll thank me when Alternative comes out.

It's difficult to talk about the Muv-Luv series without devolving into platitudes like, "an unforgettable experience," or "one of the greatest VNs of all time." That's because it truly is something special. It's an introspective epic, full of action, comedy, and pathos. I consider it a masterpiece, not only within its genre, but among all contemporary fiction.

If you are at all interested in mecha, this is a must-play. If you are enjoy military fiction (e.g. [i]Starship Troopers[/i]), you will love this. If you want visceral drama -- if you want to feel hope, horror, sadness, and relief -- this game will take your emotions for a ride. If you want to read something with intricate detail in military operations and quantum mechanics, this is it.

Yet it's difficult to recommend.

Muv-Luv is a visual novel (all story, no gameplay) originally released in 2003. It comprises the first two entries in the Muv-Luv trilogy: Muv-Luv Extra and Muv-Luv Unlimited. The final and most renowned entry, Muv-Luv Alternative, was released as a separate product in 2006, and, accordingly, the English localization will be sold separately.

If that's confusing: don't worry about it. Point is, this game is only 2/3rds of the full Muv-Luv experience, but it's the entire original game. For the purposes of this review, I'm looking at the series as a whole.

Why is Muv-Luv difficult to recommend to newcomers? The main reason is its sheer length. Extra and Unlimited together (that is, this Steam product) will probably take an average reader 40+ hours to complete. Alternative is about another 50+ hours on top of that. The whole series is bigger than most other VNs, including Clannad, Fate/stay night, and YU-NO. It has more words than [i]War and Peace[/i] twice over, or all the Harry Potter books put together. It is [b]long[/b].

If that scares you, turn back now.

Still with me? Of course, the prose is nowhere near as dense as [i]War and Peace[/i], and a very large portion is voiced dialogue that goes at a comfortable peace. The series has highly advanced graphics by VN standards, with moving sprites, traditional animation, and 3D scenes, and a phenomenal soundtrack featuring JAM Project. It's not a dry read by any means.

But compounding the issue of length is that the game doesn't fully blossom until its final part, Muv-Luv Alternative. The themes that compose its central drama are merely touched upon in Extra, and Unlimited only goes toe-deep into the pool. For that reason, there are some who advocate skipping Extra, or Extra and Unlimited, entirely.

There's some merit to the idea. Frankly, Extra isn't anything special by itself. It's a generic romantic comedy, albeit a fun and amusing one, with little of import to say. Unlimited is largely the same thing, except with a change in milieu and some minor mecha elements.

However, I strongly recommend against skipping straight to Alternative. Not only would you lose out on crucial story, foreshadowing, and character development, it would be missing the entire point of Muv-Luv.

I have been intentionally scant on plot details throughout this review, but I can safely say this: Muv-Luv is about what we take for granted. It's about the duty one bears not only to himself, but to his country and his loved ones. The protagonist, Shirogane Takeru, lives a blissful, unaware life at the story's beginning. By the end, he will be confronted and challenged time and again, forced to evaluate himself and strive toward virtue.

The banality of Extra, then, is a crucial part of the experience. It grounds ourselves (as readers) in a world similar to our own, if slightly wackier and more harem-centric. When that carefree lifestyle is taken away from our protagonist, we feel the loss too. And when glimpses of it return later on -- fragments of peace amid despair -- we cherish it all the more.

What Muv-Luv does is bold and unusual. The first 20+ hours that a reader invests into the series are of enormously different character than its greatest part. Pragmatically speaking, that isn't bearable for most people, especially since it's polarizing content in its own right (being anime-inspired, reliant on Japanese culture, etc.).

Moreover, even when Muv-Luv is at its best, it's not the sort of writing that will appeal to all tastes. Lengthy action scenes are marked by even lengthier build-ups, and there are frequent monologues during periods of reflection. And tangential “infodump” scenes break up the pace to flesh out the world and explain events in more detail than practically necessary. These aspects make for excellent immersion and worldbuilding (think [i]The Lord of the Rings[/i]), but can be off-putting to a reader looking for nothing more than hot-blooded action and drama.

So Muv-Luv is not for everybody.

But I love this game and wish for it to be loved by more. 

If you haven't played a visual novel before, but find what I've said appealing and aren't scared away by the copious amounts of moe, give it a shot! If you are a fan of visual novels but haven't played Muv-Luv, what are you waiting for? It's a masterpiece.

24326052.review:
Before I begin, I must make it clear that I have completed this release with the fan translated release, and have not yet completed the Steam release. And given how Degica chose to promote this release - by spoiling elements presented later on in Muv-Luv Unlimited in their released media - my review will cover both Extra and Unlimited and the bare story elements contained within each. Excluding that, my review will be spoiler-free. Additionally, I will rarely talk about the final part of the trilogy (Muv-Luv Alternative) in this review which plans to release on Steam in Q4 of 2016.

 

[h1]Muv-Luv Extra + Unlimited Overview[/h1]

Since its release in early 2003, the Muv-Luv trilogy has risen to be one of the most well-regarded and popular visual novels (aka VNs) ever released, with its final work, Muv-Luv Alternative, being ranked #1 on the [url=https://vndb.org/v/all?q=;fil=tagspoil-0;rfil=;o=d;s=rating]Visual Novel Database[/url] and ranked in the top three in Japan's VN rankings. Ever since its fan localization, the series has gained worldwide recognition enough to be later be the #1 most funded visual novel and ranked in the top 30 most funded video game on Kickstarter raising over $1.25 million in support. Length-wise, this two-part story spans the length of 25-40 hours varying, especially if one decides to read the extra routes presented in both.

 

[h1]UI, Translation, and Aesthetic/Music[/h1]

In comparison to the original, the UI has dramatically improved, with a beautiful options screen coated in a glorious pink containing a wide range of options. The only change I would like to see is the addition of sliders for text speed and auto-read speed instead of the default Slow, Medium, and Fast.

 

As for the translation, Degica has made a notable improvement in cleaning the rough grammar and wording that the English fan translation lacked. Additionally, there is an option for Japanese text as well (but as an non-Japanese speaker, I have a hard time evaluating it).

 

Opinions vary regarding the aesthetic of the game, but in my opinion it’s passable. Although the character designs are quite rough and outdated, they are cute and simple. My feelings are quite similar about the CG and backgrounds.

 

[h1]The Story and Thoughts[/h1]

Muv-Luv Extra follows the story of typical high school protagonist, Shirogane Takeru, and consists of a wacky slice-of-life romantic comedy involving a wide array of potential romantic interests the player can romance. Other than having a couple of interesting and absurd plot revelations, ML Extra is a pretty stereotypical romantic comedy with some interesting deviations. Apart from the two main heroines, Kagami Sumika and Meiya Mitsurugi, the other pursuable love interests are uninteresting and tropey. Despite this, ML Extra is still a passable love story with some single tear-worthy and funny moments. Although it’s nothing special, I'd still recommend reading it if one would want to read a cute romcom and for the main purpose of getting to ML Unlimited (and later ML Alternative), as those two pieces are worth the read and reward the player for reading through ML Extra.

 

Muv-Luv Unlimited consists of the same group of characters introduced in ML Extra, but setting-wise, is completely different. In this sequel, the player is introduced into a whole new world, one consisting of sci-fi technology and concepts including mechs, aliens, and much more. Originally, Unlimited was supposed to be revealed as a surprise to ML Extra players later on, but with the way Degica promoted this two-part game, any and all elements of surprise regarding this setting were abandoned. In comparison to ML Extra, little is different regarding the characters. Story-wise there's not much to praise or complain about with the bulk of it being so-so. The introduction of mechs and military certainly up the interest though and were fun elements the characters dived into. Fortunately, towards the end, there is a huge spike in quality regarding the story in its attempt to set up the player for the later masterpiece, Muv-Luv Alternative.

 

[h1]In Conclusion[/h1] (or TL;DR)

ML Extra and Unlimited are passable pieces of fiction, and although are nice in various parts, are average overall. Despite this, the reading experience was still enjoyable, and reading these two pieces are definitely worth it in preparation for reading ML Alternative in the near future, which I believe to be one of the greatest pieces of military sci-fi fiction to have ever released.

Muv-Luv is a franchise that first began as a visual novel way back in 2003, THIRTEEN years ago. It is only now that the game is officially available in English for the first time and on Steam. The Steam store page for Muv-Luv claims that it is the "most highly-acclaimed visual novel series of all time" and to be honest, that is actually possible. No VN series gained as much acclaim as Muv-Luv did, especially considering the age of the original VN. Muv-Luv to visual novels is like what Star Wars is to movies. It has gained sequels and spin-offs in the form of other VNs, manga and anime.

The Muv-Luv VN that you can purchase here is a story that comprises of two arcs; Extra and Unlimited. Extra starts out as what you can call your "basic VN love story" where the hero has to choose between girls but when the Unlimited arc starts, things kick into high gear. The series explores storytelling elements like timelines or alternate realities but what is prominent in all Muv-Luv media since the Unlimited arc is the fight of the human characters against aliens called the BETA (Beings of the Extra Terrestrial origin which is Adversary of human race). And fans are drawn to the franchise's own spin on giant robots called TSFs (Tactical Surface Fighters). Unlike many other Japanese franchises, TSFs are named and based on real-world military aircraft. My favorite for example is the F-22A Raptor.

Since this is a VN, the gameplay (or lack of, if you're cynical) is what you would expect. Muv-Luv follows a linear plot line, which offers pre-determined scenarios and courses of interaction, and focuses on the differing scenarios of the female main characters. Personally, I think Muv-Luv has a lot more choices than most visual novels and the game has multiple plot lines that the player can follow, one for each heroine in the story, and there's supposedly nineteen possible endings. The game even fails you for making the wrong decision. To view all the plotlines, it is highly recommended to replay the game and make different decisions.

All in all, if you're into VNs, Muv-Luv is more than worth it to purchase and play through many times. It has an interesting world, characters and plot. You won't regret getting invested in the story. However, if you're not the type that plays visual novels or can't stand that much reading, then obviously it's best that you move on and play something else. If you play it and enjoy it, the story doesn't end there. Unlimited is followed by Muv-Luv: Alternative which should be released by the end of the year. And yes, there's going to be a R18+ patch, apparently. You can never have enough "plot". 

P.S. Despite what you hear from some people who already know the story, DON'T SKIP EXTRA!!! Yes, the game gives you the option of going straight into Unlimited which is the more "exciting" arc but if you truly want the full experience, play Extra first, ESPECIALLY if this is your first time playing Muv-Luv. Don't be afraid that you'll be wasting time just because somebody else says you would.

24325960.review:
TL;DR: The Muv-Luv trilogy is a must-read for anyone who calls themself a fan of visual novels. That said, its legendary status is only made apparent after reading all three games: Extra, Unlimited, and Alternative (note that this Steam title includes both Extra and Unlimited). While I would be cautious to recommend only Extra and Unlimited, I wholeheartedly recommend them in the context of the entire trilogy. Extra is redeemed by Unlimited and you will be thoroughly rewarded with Alternative.

This is a difficult game to explain without spoilers. So difficult, in fact, that the official Steam description and preview video delve into spoiler territory. Regardless, I will try to stay spoiler-free.

Muv-Luv is a visual novel trilogy and franchise that is highly celebrated in both Japan and the west. On EGS (Japanese), Alternative is ranked the #3 VN of all time. On VNDB (English), Alternative is ranked the #1 VN of all time by a significant margin (July 2016).

This Steam title, Muv-Luv, includes the first two parts of the trilogy: Muv-Luv Extra and Muv-Luv Unlimited.

I implore you to not skip straight to Unlimited (Part 2). Extra (Part 1), despite being slow, is a requirement to fully set the characters and tone for the sequels. This series truly is something special, but only when read in full.

Muv-Luv Extra is your generic anime high-school rom-com. The MC, Takeru, is your generic self-insert protagonist. Meiya is the generic affluent ojou-sama. Sumika is the generic short-tempered childhood friend. Ayamine is the generic Rei expy. I could go on.

While Extra is not terrible, it's nothing special on its own. It's leagues better than many VNs on Steam, that's for sure, but its real purpose is to build up the characters and set the scene for the remaining two games.

Unlimited--which is included in this release--is where things start to get unique and interesting (sci-fi, mecha, drama) but you must read Extra to fully appreciate it (and also to eventually appreciate Alternative, which is god-tier).

ART: Despite being an old game, Muv-Luv's art holds up surprisingly well. The rUGP engine was ahead of its time, and that helps breathe life into the visuals for Muv-Luv. The artwork itself, while aged, has an undeniable charm that keeps it fresh even in the age of perfectly polished HD assets.

MUSIC: You may have heard that Muv-Luv has an incredible soundtrack. Anyone saying that is referring to Alternative, which does have a phenomenal OST. Unfortunately, this is not true for Extra nor Unlimited. The slice of life soundtracks are repetitive in the worst way and there's not a wide variety of them.

VOICE: The voices, overall, are pretty good. I would prefer to have a fully voiced MC, but the performances from the rest of the voice actors make up for it.

ANIMATION: Muv-Luv was made long before the Live-2D or e-Mote systems were implemented and stood out as having brilliant animation for its time. The animation, especially in this renewed edition, still stands strong. You won't see most of the animated scenes until Unlimited (and only then ultimately polished in Alternative), but these scenes further down the line make you feel like you're watching a well-choreographed cutscene.

STORY: The series is praised for good reason. Unfortunately, it doesn't shine until Unlimited and doesn't fully blossom until Alternative. You will have to trust me on this one: Extra is a slow trudge, but you'll be happy to have not skipped it when reading Alternative.

This ended up longer than I expected. Should you buy this game? Yes, absolutely. But you must also buy and play Alternative for the full experience.
